Fitted Q-Iteration Methods

The previous chapter established the theoretical foundations of simulation-based approximate dynamic programming: Monte Carlo integration for evaluating expectations, Q-functions for efficient action selection, and techniques for mitigating overestimation bias. Those developments assumed we could sample freely from transition distributions and choose optimization parameters without constraint. This chapter develops a unified framework for fitted Q-iteration algorithms that spans both offline and online settings. We begin with batch algorithms that learn from fixed datasets, then show how the same template generates online methods like DQN through systematic variations in data collection, optimization strategy, and function approximation.

Design Choices in FQI Methods¶

All FQI methods share the same two-level structure built on three core ingredients: a buffer Bt\mathcal{B}_tBt​ of transitions inducing an empirical distribution P^Bt\hat{P}_{\mathcal{B}_t}P^Bt​​, a target function ggg that computes regression targets from the current Q-function, and an optimization procedure to fit the Q-function to the resulting targets. At iteration nnn, the outer loop constructs targets from individual transitions using the target function: for each transition (si,ai,ri,si′)(s_i, a_i, r_i, s'_i)(si​,ai​,ri​,si′​), we compute yi(n)=g(si,ai,ri,si′;θn)y_i^{(n)} = g(s_i, a_i, r_i, s'_i; \boldsymbol{\theta}_n)yi(n)​=g(si​,ai​,ri​,si′​;θn​) where typically g(s,a,r,s′;θ)=r+γmax⁡a′q(s′,a′;θ)g(s,a,r,s'; \boldsymbol{\theta}) = r + \gamma \max_{a'} q(s',a'; \boldsymbol{\theta})g(s,a,r,s′;θ)=r+γmaxa′​q(s′,a′;θ). The inner loop solves the regression problem min⁡θE((s,a),y)∼P^nfit[ℓ(q(s,a;θ),y)]\min_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \mathbb{E}_{((s,a),y) \sim \hat{P}_n^{\text{fit}}}[\ell(q(s, a; \boldsymbol{\theta}), y)]minθ​E((s,a),y)∼P^nfit​​[ℓ(q(s,a;θ),y)] to find parameters that match these targets. We can write this abstractly as:

repeat n=0,1,2,…Sample transitions from P^Bn and construct targets via g(⋅;θn)θ(n+1)←fit(P^nfit,θinit,K)until convergence\begin{aligned} &\textbf{repeat } n = 0, 1, 2, \ldots \\ &\quad \text{Sample transitions from } \hat{P}_{\mathcal{B}_n} \text{ and construct targets via } g(\cdot; \boldsymbol{\theta}_n) \\ &\quad \boldsymbol{\theta}^{(n+1)} \leftarrow \texttt{fit}(\hat{P}_n^{\text{fit}}, \boldsymbol{\theta}_{\text{init}}, K) \\ &\textbf{until } \text{convergence} \end{aligned}​repeat n=0,1,2,…Sample transitions from P^Bn​​ and construct targets via g(⋅;θn​)θ(n+1)←fit(P^nfit​,θinit​,K)until convergence​
(1)

The fit operation minimizes the regression loss using KKK optimization steps (gradient descent for neural networks, tree construction for ensembles, matrix inversion for linear models) starting from initialization θinit\boldsymbol{\theta}_{\text{init}}θinit​. Standard supervised learning uses random initialization (θinit=θ0\boldsymbol{\theta}_{\text{init}} = \boldsymbol{\theta}_0θinit​=θ0​) and runs to convergence (K=∞K = \inftyK=∞). Reinforcement learning algorithms vary these choices: warm starting from the previous iteration (θinit=θ(n)\boldsymbol{\theta}_{\text{init}} = \boldsymbol{\theta}^{(n)}θinit​=θ(n)), partial optimization (K∈{10,…,100}K \in \{10, \ldots, 100\}K∈{10,…,100}), or single-step updates (K=1K=1K=1).

The buffer Bt\mathcal{B}_tBt​ may stay fixed (batch setting) or change (online setting), but the targets always change because they depend on the evolving target function g(⋅;θn)g(\cdot; \boldsymbol{\theta}_n)g(⋅;θn​). In practice, we typically have one observed next state per transition, giving g(si,ai,ri,si′;θ)=ri+γmax⁡a′q(si′,a′;θ)g(s_i, a_i, r_i, s'_i; \boldsymbol{\theta}) = r_i + \gamma \max_{a'} q(s'_i, a'; \boldsymbol{\theta})g(si​,ai​,ri​,si′​;θ)=ri​+γmaxa′​q(si′​,a′;θ) for transition tuples (si,ai,ri,si′)(s_i, a_i, r_i, s'_i)(si​,ai​,ri​,si′​).

Remark 1 (Notation: Buffer vs Regression Distribution)

We maintain a careful distinction between two empirical distributions throughout:

  • Buffer distribution P^Bt\hat{P}_{\mathcal{B}_t}P^Bt​​ over transitions τ=(s,a,r,s′)\tau = (s, a, r, s')τ=(s,a,r,s′): The empirical distribution induced by the replay buffer Bt\mathcal{B}_tBt​, which contains raw experience tuples. This is fixed (offline) or evolves via online collection (adding new transitions, dropping old ones).

  • Regression distribution P^tfit\hat{P}_t^{\text{fit}}P^tfit​ over pairs ((s,a),y)((s,a), y)((s,a),y): The empirical distribution over supervised learning targets. This changes every outer iteration nnn as we recompute targets using the current target function g(⋅;θn)g(\cdot; \boldsymbol{\theta}_n)g(⋅;θn​).

The relationship: at iteration nnn, we construct P^nfit\hat{P}_n^{\text{fit}}P^nfit​ from P^Bn\hat{P}_{\mathcal{B}_n}P^Bn​​ by applying the target function:

P^nfit=(id,g(⋅;θn))#P^Bn\hat{P}_n^{\text{fit}} = (\mathrm{id}, g(\cdot; \boldsymbol{\theta}_n))_\# \hat{P}_{\mathcal{B}_n}P^nfit​=(id,g(⋅;θn​))#​P^Bn​​
(2)

where g(s,a,r,s′;θn)=r+γmax⁡a′q(s′,a′;θn)g(s,a,r,s'; \boldsymbol{\theta}_n) = r + \gamma \max_{a'} q(s', a'; \boldsymbol{\theta}_n)g(s,a,r,s′;θn​)=r+γmaxa′​q(s′,a′;θn​) or uses the smooth logsumexp operator.

This distinction matters pedagogically: the buffer distribution P^Bt\hat{P}_{\mathcal{B}_t}P^Bt​​ is fixed (offline) or evolves via online collection, while the regression distribution P^tfit\hat{P}_t^{\text{fit}}P^tfit​ evolves via target recomputation. Fitted Q-iteration is the outer loop over target recomputation, not the inner loop over gradient steps.

This template provides a blueprint for instantiating concrete algorithms. Six design axes generate algorithmic diversity: the function approximator (trees, neural networks, linear models), the Bellman operator (hard max vs smooth logsumexp, discussed in the regularized MDP chapter), the inner optimization strategy (full convergence, KKK steps, or single step), the initialization scheme (cold vs warm start), the data collection mechanism (offline, online, replay buffer), and bias mitigation approaches (none, double Q-learning, learned correction). While individual algorithms include additional refinements, these axes capture the primary sources of variation. The table below shows how several well-known methods instantiate this template:

AlgorithmApproximatorBellmanInner LoopInitializationDataBias Fix
FQI Ernst et al. (2005)Extra TreesHardFullColdOfflineNone
NFQI Riedmiller (2005)Neural NetHardFullWarmOfflineNone
Q-learning Watkins (1989)AnyHardK=1WarmOnlineNone
DQN Mnih et al. (2013)Deep NNHardK=1WarmReplayNone
Double DQN Van Hasselt et al. (2016)Deep NNHardK=1WarmReplayDouble Q
Soft Q Haarnoja et al. (2017)Neural NetSmoothK stepsWarmReplayNone

This table omits continuous action methods (NFQCA, DDPG, SAC), which introduce an additional design dimension. We address those in the continuous action chapter. The initialization choice becomes particularly important when moving from batch to online algorithms.

Plug-In Approximation with Empirical Distributions¶

The exact Bellman operator involves expectations under the true transition law (combined with the behavior policy), which we denote abstractly by PPP over transitions τ=(s,a,r,s′)\tau = (s,a,r,s')τ=(s,a,r,s′):

(Lq)(s,a)=r(s,a)+γ∫max⁡a′q(s′,a′) P(ds′∣s,a)(\Bellman q)(s,a) = r(s,a) + \gamma \int \max_{a'} q(s',a')\, P(ds' \mid s,a)(Lq)(s,a)=r(s,a)+γ∫a′max​q(s′,a′)P(ds′∣s,a)
(3)

In fitted Q-iteration we never see PPP directly. Instead, we collect a finite set of transitions in a buffer Bt={τ1,…,τ∣Bt∣}\mathcal{B}_t = \{\tau_1,\dots,\tau_{|\mathcal{B}_t|}\}Bt​={τ1​,…,τ∣Bt​∣​} and work with the empirical distribution

P^Bt=1∣Bt∣∑τ∈Btδτ\hat{P}_{\mathcal{B}_t} = \frac{1}{|\mathcal{B}_t|} \sum_{\tau \in \mathcal{B}_t} \delta_\tauP^Bt​​=∣Bt​∣1​τ∈Bt​∑​δτ​
(4)

where δτ\delta_\tauδτ​ denotes a Dirac delta (point mass) centered at transition τ\tauτ. Each δτ\delta_\tauδτ​ is a probability distribution that places mass 1 at the single point τ\tauτ and mass 0 everywhere else. The sum creates a mixture distribution: a uniform distribution over the finite set of observed transitions. Sampling from P^Bt\hat{P}_{\mathcal{B}_t}P^Bt​​ means picking one transition uniformly at random from the buffer.

For any integrand g(τ)g(\tau)g(τ) (loss, TD error, gradient term), expectations under PPP are approximated by expectations under P^Bt\hat{P}_{\mathcal{B}_t}P^Bt​​ using the sample average estimator:

Eτ∼P[g(τ)]  ≈  Eτ∼P^Bt[g(τ)]=1∣Bt∣∑τ∈Btg(τ)\mathbb{E}_{\tau \sim P}\big[g(\tau)\big] \;\approx\; \mathbb{E}_{\tau \sim \hat{P}_{\mathcal{B}_t}}\big[g(\tau)\big] = \frac{1}{|\mathcal{B}_t|} \sum_{\tau \in \mathcal{B}_t} g(\tau)Eτ∼P​[g(τ)]≈Eτ∼P^Bt​​​[g(τ)]=∣Bt​∣1​τ∈Bt​∑​g(τ)
(5)

This is exactly the sample average estimator from the Monte Carlo chapter, applied now to transitions. Conceptually, fitted Q-iteration performs plug-in approximate dynamic programming. The plug-in principle is a general approach from statistics: when an algorithm requires an unknown population quantity, substitute its sample-based estimator. Here, we replace the unknown transition law PPP with the empirical distribution P^Bt\hat{P}_{\mathcal{B}_t}P^Bt​​ and run value iteration using this empirical Bellman operator:

(L^Btq)(s,a)≜r(s,a)+γ  E(r′,s′)∣(s,a)∼P^Bt[max⁡a′q(s′,a′)](\widehat{\Bellman}_{\mathcal{B}_t} q)(s,a) \triangleq r(s,a) + \gamma\; \mathbb{E}_{(r',s') \mid (s,a)\sim \hat{P}_{\mathcal{B}_t}} \Big[\max_{a'} q(s',a')\Big](LBt​​q)(s,a)≜r(s,a)+γE(r′,s′)∣(s,a)∼P^Bt​​​[a′max​q(s′,a′)]
(6)

From a computational viewpoint, we could describe all of this using sample averages and mini-batch gradients. The empirical distribution notation provides three benefits. First, it unifies offline and online algorithms: both perform value iteration under an empirical law P^Bt\hat{P}_{\mathcal{B}_t}P^Bt​​, differing only in whether Bt\mathcal{B}_tBt​ remains fixed or evolves. Second, it shows that methods like DQN perform stochastic optimization of a sample average approximation objective Eτ∼P^Bt[ℓ(⋅)]\mathbb{E}_{\tau \sim \hat{P}_{\mathcal{B}_t}}[\ell(\cdot)]Eτ∼P^Bt​​​[ℓ(⋅)], not some ad hoc non-stationary procedure. Third, it cleanly separates two sources of approximation that we will examine shortly: statistical bootstrap (resampling from P^Bt\hat{P}_{\mathcal{B}_t}P^Bt​​) versus temporal-difference bootstrap (using estimated values in targets).

Remark 2 (Mathematical Formulation of Empirical Distributions)

The empirical distribution P^Bt=1∣Bt∣∑τ∈Btδτ\hat{P}_{\mathcal{B}_t} = \frac{1}{|\mathcal{B}_t|}\sum_{\tau \in \mathcal{B}_t} \delta_{\tau}P^Bt​​=∣Bt​∣1​∑τ∈Bt​​δτ​ is a discrete probability measure over ∣Bt∣|\mathcal{B}_t|∣Bt​∣ points regardless of whether state and action spaces are continuous or discrete. For any measurable set A⊆S×A×R×SA \subseteq \mathcal{S} \times \mathcal{A} \times \mathbb{R} \times \mathcal{S}A⊆S×A×R×S:

P^Bt(A)=1∣Bt∣∑τ∈Bt1[τ∈A]=∣{τ∈Bt:τ∈A}∣∣Bt∣\hat{P}_{\mathcal{B}_t}(A) = \frac{1}{|\mathcal{B}_t|}\sum_{\tau \in \mathcal{B}_t} \mathbb{1}[\tau \in A] = \frac{|\{\tau \in \mathcal{B}_t : \tau \in A\}|}{|\mathcal{B}_t|}P^Bt​​(A)=∣Bt​∣1​τ∈Bt​∑​1[τ∈A]=∣Bt​∣∣{τ∈Bt​:τ∈A}∣​
(7)

The empirical distribution assigns probability 1/∣Bt∣1/|\mathcal{B}_t|1/∣Bt​∣ to each observed tuple and zero elsewhere.

Data, Buffers, and the Unified Template¶

Fitted Q-iteration is built around three ingredients at any time ttt:

  1. A replay buffer Bt\mathcal{B}_tBt​ containing transitions, inducing an empirical distribution P^Bt\hat{P}_{\mathcal{B}_t}P^Bt​​

  2. A target function g(s,a,r,s′;θ):S×A×R×S×Θ↦Rg(s,a,r,s'; \boldsymbol{\theta}) : \mathcal{S} \times \mathcal{A} \times \mathbb{R} \times \mathcal{S} \times \Theta \mapsto \mathbb{R}g(s,a,r,s′;θ):S×A×R×S×Θ↦R that computes regression targets for individual transitions. Unlike the Bellman operator T\mathcal{T}T which acts on function spaces, ggg operates on transition tuples with parameters θ\boldsymbol{\theta}θ (after the semicolon) specifying the current Q-function. Typically g(s,a,r,s′;θ)=r+γmax⁡a′q(s′,a′;θ)g(s,a,r,s'; \boldsymbol{\theta}) = r + \gamma \max_{a'} q(s',a'; \boldsymbol{\theta})g(s,a,r,s′;θ)=r+γmaxa′​q(s′,a′;θ) (hard max) or uses the smooth logsumexp operator.

  3. A loss function ℓ\ellℓ and optimization budget (replay ratio, number of gradient steps)

Pushing transitions through the target function transforms P^Bt\hat{P}_{\mathcal{B}_t}P^Bt​​ into a regression distribution P^tfit\hat{P}_t^{\text{fit}}P^tfit​ over pairs ((s,a),y)((s,a), y)((s,a),y), as described in the notation remark above. The inner loop minimizes the empirical risk E((s,a),y)∼P^tfit[ℓ(q(s,a;θ),y)]\mathbb{E}_{((s,a),y)\sim \hat{P}_t^{\text{fit}}} [\ell(q(s,a;\boldsymbol{\theta}), y)]E((s,a),y)∼P^tfit​​[ℓ(q(s,a;θ),y)] via stochastic gradient descent on mini-batches.

Different algorithms correspond to different ways of evolving the buffer Bt\mathcal{B}_tBt​ and different replay ratios:

  • Offline FQI. We start from a fixed dataset D\mathcal{D}D and never collect new data. The buffer is constant, Bt≡D\mathcal{B}_t \equiv \mathcal{D}Bt​≡D and P^Bt≡P^D\hat{P}_{\mathcal{B}_t} \equiv \hat{P}_{\mathcal{D}}P^Bt​​≡P^D​, and only the target function g(⋅;θt)g(\cdot; \boldsymbol{\theta}_t)g(⋅;θt​) changes as the Q-function evolves.

  • Replay (DQN-style). The buffer is a circular buffer of fixed capacity BBB. At each interaction step we append the new transition and, if the buffer is full, drop the oldest one: Bt={τt−B+1,…,τt}\mathcal{B}_t = \{\tau_{t-B+1},\ldots,\tau_t\}Bt​={τt−B+1​,…,τt​} and P^Bt=1∣Bt∣∑τ∈Btδτ\hat{P}_{\mathcal{B}_t} = \frac{1}{|\mathcal{B}_t|} \sum_{\tau \in \mathcal{B}_t} \delta_{\tau}P^Bt​​=∣Bt​∣1​∑τ∈Bt​​δτ​. The empirical distribution slides forward through time, but at each update we still sample uniformly from the current buffer.

  • Fully online Q-learning. Tabular Q-learning is the degenerate case with buffer size B=1B=1B=1: we only keep the most recent transition. Then P^Bt\hat{P}_{\mathcal{B}_t}P^Bt​​ is supported on a single point and each update uses that one sample once.

The replay ratio (optimization steps per environment transition) quantifies data reuse:

Replay ratio={K⋅Nepochs⋅N/bOffline (batch size b from N transitions)bDQN (one step per transition, batch size b)1Online Q-learning\text{Replay ratio} = \begin{cases} K \cdot N_{\text{epochs}} \cdot N / b & \text{Offline (batch size } b \text{ from } N \text{ transitions)} \\ b & \text{DQN (one step per transition, batch size } b \text{)} \\ 1 & \text{Online Q-learning} \end{cases}Replay ratio=⎩⎨⎧​K⋅Nepochs​⋅N/bb1​Offline (batch size b from N transitions)DQN (one step per transition, batch size b)Online Q-learning​
(8)

where KKK is the number of gradient steps per outer iteration. Large replay ratios reuse the same empirical distribution P^Bt\hat{P}_{\mathcal{B}_t}P^Bt​​ many times, implementing sample average approximation (offline FQI). Small replay ratios use each sample once, implementing stochastic approximation (online Q-learning). Higher replay ratios reduce variance of estimates under P^Bt\hat{P}_{\mathcal{B}_t}P^Bt​​ but risk overfitting to the idiosyncrasies of the current empirical law, especially when it reflects outdated policies or narrow coverage.

Remark 3 (Two Notions of Bootstrap)

This perspective separates two different “bootstraps” that appear in FQI:

  1. Statistical bootstrap over data. By sampling with replacement from P^Bt\hat{P}_{\mathcal{B}_t}P^Bt​​, we approximate expectations under the (unknown) transition distribution PPP with expectations under the empirical distribution P^Bt\hat{P}_{\mathcal{B}_t}P^Bt​​. This is identical to bootstrap resampling in statistics. Mini-batch training is exactly this: we treat the observed transitions as if they were the entire population and approximate expectations by repeatedly resampling from the empirical law. The replay ratio controls how many such bootstrap samples we take per environment interaction.

  2. Temporal-difference bootstrap over values. When we compute y=r+γmax⁡a′q(s′,a′;θ)y = r + \gamma \max_{a'} q(s',a';\boldsymbol{\theta})y=r+γmaxa′​q(s′,a′;θ), we replace the unknown continuation value by our current estimate. This is the TD notion of bootstrapping and the source of maximization bias studied in the previous chapter.

FQI, DQN, and their variants combine both: the empirical distribution P^Bt\hat{P}_{\mathcal{B}_t}P^Bt​​ encodes how we reuse data (statistical bootstrap), and the target function ggg encodes how we bootstrap values (TD bootstrap). Most bias-correction techniques (Keane–Wolpin, Double Q-learning, Gumbel losses) modify the second kind of bootstrapping while leaving the statistical bootstrap unchanged.

Every algorithm in this chapter minimizes an empirical risk of the form E((s,a),y)∼P^tfit[ℓ(q(s,a;θ),y)]\mathbb{E}_{((s,a),y)\sim \hat{P}_t^{\text{fit}}} [\ell(q(s,a;\boldsymbol{\theta}), y)]E((s,a),y)∼P^tfit​​[ℓ(q(s,a;θ),y)], where expectations are computed via the sample average estimator over the buffer. Algorithmic diversity arises from choices of buffer evolution, target function, loss, and optimization schedule.

Batch Algorithms: Ernst’s FQI and NFQI¶

We begin with the simplest case from the buffer perspective. We are given a fixed transition dataset D={(si,ai,ri,si′)}i=1N\mathcal{D} = \{(s_i,a_i,r_i,s'_i)\}_{i=1}^ND={(si​,ai​,ri​,si′​)}i=1N​ and never collect new data. The replay buffer is frozen:

Bt≡D,P^Bt≡P^D\mathcal{B}_t \equiv \mathcal{D}, \qquad \hat{P}_{\mathcal{B}_t} \equiv \hat{P}_{\mathcal{D}}Bt​≡D,P^Bt​​≡P^D​
(9)

so the only thing that changes across iterations is the target function g(⋅;θn)g(\cdot; \boldsymbol{\theta}_n)g(⋅;θn​) induced by the current Q-function. Every outer iteration of FQI samples from the same empirical distribution P^D\hat{P}_{\mathcal{D}}P^D​ but pushes it through a new target function, producing a new regression distribution P^nfit\hat{P}_n^{\text{fit}}P^nfit​.

At each outer iteration nnn, we construct the input set X(n)={(si,ai)}i=1NX^{(n)} = \{(s_i, a_i)\}_{i=1}^NX(n)={(si​,ai​)}i=1N​ from the same transitions (the state-action pairs remain fixed), compute targets yi(n)=g(si,ai,ri,si′;θ(n))=ri+γmax⁡a′q(si′,a′;θ(n))y_i^{(n)} = g(s_i, a_i, r_i, s'_i; \boldsymbol{\theta}^{(n)}) = r_i + \gamma \max_{a'} q(s'_i, a'; \boldsymbol{\theta}^{(n)})yi(n)​=g(si​,ai​,ri​,si′​;θ(n))=ri​+γmaxa′​q(si′​,a′;θ(n)) using the current Q-function, and solve the regression problem θ(n+1)←fit(X(n),y(n),θinit,K)\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(n+1)} \leftarrow \texttt{fit}(X^{(n)}, y^{(n)}, \boldsymbol{\theta}_{\text{init}}, K)θ(n+1)←fit(X(n),y(n),θinit​,K). The buffer Bt=D\mathcal{B}_t = \mathcal{D}Bt​=D never changes, but the targets change at every iteration because they depend on the evolving target function g(⋅;θn)g(\cdot; \boldsymbol{\theta}_n)g(⋅;θn​). Each transition (si,ai,ri,si′)(s_i, a_i, r_i, s'_i)(si​,ai​,ri​,si′​) provides a single Monte Carlo sample si′s'_isi′​ for evaluating the Bellman operator at (si,ai)(s_i, a_i)(si​,ai​), giving us L^1q\widehat{\Bellman}_1 qL1​q with N=1N=1N=1.

The following algorithm is simply approximate value iteration where expectations under the transition kernel PPP are replaced by expectations under the fixed empirical distribution P^D\hat{P}_{\mathcal{D}}P^D​:

Algorithm 1 (Generic Fitted Q-Iteration (Batch))

Input: Dataset D={(si,ai,ri,si′)}i=1N\mathcal{D} = \{(s_i, a_i, r_i, s'_i)\}_{i=1}^ND={(si​,ai​,ri​,si′​)}i=1N​, function approximator q(s,a;θ)q(s,a; \boldsymbol{\theta})q(s,a;θ), discount factor γ\gammaγ, maximum iterations nmax⁡n_{\max}nmax​

Output: Learned Q-function parameters θ\boldsymbol{\theta}θ

  1. Initialize θ0\boldsymbol{\theta}_0θ0​

  2. n←0n \leftarrow 0n←0

  3. repeat \quad // Outer loop: Value Iteration

  4. \quad // Construct regression dataset with Bellman targets

  5. \quad X(n)←{(si,ai):(si,ai,ri,si′)∈D}X^{(n)} \leftarrow \{(s_i, a_i) : (s_i, a_i, r_i, s'_i) \in \mathcal{D}\}X(n)←{(si​,ai​):(si​,ai​,ri​,si′​)∈D}

  6. \quad for each (si,ai,ri,si′)∈D(s_i, a_i, r_i, s'_i) \in \mathcal{D}(si​,ai​,ri​,si′​)∈D do

  7. \quad\quad yi(n)←ri+γmax⁡a′∈Aq(si′,a′;θn)y_i^{(n)} \leftarrow r_i + \gamma \max_{a' \in \mathcal{A}} q(s'_i, a'; \boldsymbol{\theta}_n)yi(n)​←ri​+γmaxa′∈A​q(si′​,a′;θn​)

  8. \quad end for

  9. \quad // Inner loop: Fit Q-function to targets (projection step)

  10. \quad θn+1←fit(X(n),y(n),θinit,K)\boldsymbol{\theta}_{n+1} \leftarrow \texttt{fit}(X^{(n)}, y^{(n)}, \boldsymbol{\theta}_{\text{init}}, K)θn+1​←fit(X(n),y(n),θinit​,K)

  11. \quad n←n+1n \leftarrow n+1n←n+1

  12. until convergence or n≥nmax⁡n \geq n_{\max}n≥nmax​

  13. return θn\boldsymbol{\theta}_nθn​

The fit operation in line 10 abstracts the inner optimization loop that minimizes ∑i=1Nℓ(q(si,ai;θ),yi(n))\sum_{i=1}^N \ell(q(s_i, a_i; \boldsymbol{\theta}), y_i^{(n)})∑i=1N​ℓ(q(si​,ai​;θ),yi(n)​). This line encodes the algorithmic choice of which function approximator to use and how to optimize it. The initialization θinit\boldsymbol{\theta}_{\text{init}}θinit​ and number of optimization steps KKK control whether we use cold or warm starting and whether we optimize to convergence or perform partial updates.

Fitted Q-Iteration (FQI): Ernst et al. Ernst et al. (2005) instantiate this template with extremely randomized trees (extra trees), an ensemble method that partitions the state-action space into regions with piecewise constant Q-values. The fit operation trains the ensemble until completion using the tree construction algorithm. Trees handle high-dimensional inputs naturally and the ensemble reduces overfitting. FQI uses cold start initialization: θinit=θ0\boldsymbol{\theta}_{\text{init}} = \boldsymbol{\theta}_0θinit​=θ0​ (randomly initialized) at every iteration, since trees don’t naturally support incremental refinement. The loss ℓ\ellℓ is squared error. This method demonstrated that batch reinforcement learning could work with complex function approximators on continuous-state problems.

Neural Fitted Q-Iteration (NFQI): Riedmiller Riedmiller (2005) replaces the tree ensemble with a neural network q(s,a;θ)q(s,a; \boldsymbol{\theta})q(s,a;θ), providing smooth interpolation across the state-action space. The fit operation runs gradient-based optimization (RProp, chosen for its insensitivity to hyperparameter choices) to convergence: train the network until the loss stops decreasing (multiple epochs through the full dataset D\mathcal{D}D), corresponding to K=∞K=\inftyK=∞ in our framework. NFQI uses warm start initialization: θinit=θn\boldsymbol{\theta}_{\text{init}} = \boldsymbol{\theta}_nθinit​=θn​ at iteration nnn, meaning the network continues learning from the previous iteration’s weights rather than resetting. This ensures the network accurately represents the projected Bellman operator before moving to the next outer iteration. For episodic tasks with goal and forbidden regions, Riedmiller uses modified target computations (detailed below).

Remark 4 (Goal State Heuristics in NFQI)

For episodic tasks with goal states S+S^+S+ and forbidden states S−S^-S−, Riedmiller modifies the target structure:

yi(n)={c(si,ai,si′)if si′∈S+ (goal reached)C−if si′∈S− (forbidden state, typically C−=1.0)c(si,ai,si′)+γmax⁡a′q(si′,a′;θn)otherwisey_i^{(n)} = \begin{cases} c(s_i, a_i, s'_i) & \text{if } s'_i \in S^+ \text{ (goal reached)} \\ C^- & \text{if } s'_i \in S^- \text{ (forbidden state, typically } C^- = 1.0\text{)} \\ c(s_i, a_i, s'_i) + \gamma \max_{a'} q(s'_i, a'; \boldsymbol{\theta}_n) & \text{otherwise} \end{cases}yi(n)​=⎩⎨⎧​c(si​,ai​,si′​)C−c(si​,ai​,si′​)+γmaxa′​q(si′​,a′;θn​)​if si′​∈S+ (goal reached)if si′​∈S− (forbidden state, typically C−=1.0)otherwise​
(10)

where c(s,a,s′)c(s, a, s')c(s,a,s′) is the immediate cost. Goal states have zero future cost (no bootstrapping), forbidden states have high penalty, and regular states use the standard Bellman backup. Additionally, the hint-to-goal heuristic adds synthetic transitions (s,a,s′)(s, a, s')(s,a,s′) where s∈S+s \in S^+s∈S+ with target value c(s,a,s′)=0c(s,a,s') = 0c(s,a,s′)=0 to explicitly clamp the Q-function to zero in the goal region. This stabilizes learning by encoding the boundary condition without requiring additional prior knowledge.

From Nested to Flattened Q-Iteration¶

Fitted Q-iteration has an inherently nested structure: an outer loop performs approximate value iteration by computing Bellman targets, and an inner loop performs regression by fitting the function approximator to those targets. This nested structure shows that FQI is approximate dynamic programming with function approximation, distinct from supervised learning with changing targets.

When the inner loop uses gradient descent for KKK steps, we have:

fit(Dnfit,θn,K)=θn−α∑k=0K−1∇θL(θn(k);Dnfit)\texttt{fit}(\mathcal{D}_n^{\text{fit}}, \boldsymbol{\theta}_n, K) = \boldsymbol{\theta}_n - \alpha \sum_{k=0}^{K-1} \nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta}_n^{(k)}; \mathcal{D}_n^{\text{fit}})fit(Dnfit​,θn​,K)=θn​−αk=0∑K−1​∇θ​L(θn(k)​;Dnfit​)
(11)

This is a sequence of updates θn(k+1)=θn(k)−α∇θL(θn(k);Dnfit)\boldsymbol{\theta}_n^{(k+1)} = \boldsymbol{\theta}_n^{(k)} - \alpha \nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta}_n^{(k)}; \mathcal{D}_n^{\text{fit}})θn(k+1)​=θn(k)​−α∇θ​L(θn(k)​;Dnfit​) for k=0,…,K−1k = 0, \ldots, K-1k=0,…,K−1 starting from θn(0)=θn\boldsymbol{\theta}_n^{(0)} = \boldsymbol{\theta}_nθn(0)​=θn​. Since these inner updates are themselves a loop, we can algebraically rewrite the nested loops as a single flattened loop. This flattening is purely representational. The algorithm remains approximate value iteration, but the presentation obscures the conceptual structure.

In the flattened form, the parameters used for computing targets are called the target network θtarget\boldsymbol{\theta}_{\text{target}}θtarget​, which corresponds to θn\boldsymbol{\theta}_nθn​ in the nested form. The target network gets updated every KKK steps, marking the boundaries between outer iterations.

In contrast, the parameters being actively trained via gradient descent at each step are called the online network θt\boldsymbol{\theta}_tθt​. In the nested view, these correspond to θn(k)\boldsymbol{\theta}_n^{(k)}θn(k)​ within the inner loop. The term “online” here refers to the fact that these parameters are continuously updated at each gradient step, not that data must be collected online. The distinction is between the actively-training parameters (θt\boldsymbol{\theta}_tθt​) and the frozen parameters used for target computation (θtarget\boldsymbol{\theta}_{\text{target}}θtarget​).

The online/target terminology is standard in the deep RL community. Many modern algorithms, especially those that collect data online like DQN, are presented in flattened form. This can make them appear different from batch methods when they are the same template with different design choices.

Tree ensemble methods like random forests or extra trees have no continuous parameter space and no gradient-based optimization. The fit operation builds the entire tree structure in one pass. There’s no sequence of incremental updates to unfold into a single loop. Ernst’s FQI Ernst et al. (2005) retains the explicit nested structure with cold start initialization at each outer iteration, while neural methods can be flattened.

Making the Nested Structure Explicit¶

To see how flattening works, we first make the nested structure completely explicit by expanding the fit operation to show the inner gradient descent loop. In terms of the buffer notation, the inner loop approximately minimizes the empirical risk:

E((s,a),y)∼P^nfit[ℓ(q(s,a;θ),y)]\mathbb{E}_{((s,a),y)\sim \hat{P}_n^{\text{fit}}}[\ell(q(s,a;\boldsymbol{\theta}), y)]E((s,a),y)∼P^nfit​​[ℓ(q(s,a;θ),y)]
(12)

induced by the fixed buffer Bn=D\mathcal{B}_n = \mathcal{D}Bn​=D and target function g(⋅;θn)g(\cdot; \boldsymbol{\theta}_n)g(⋅;θn​). Starting from the generic batch FQI template (Algorithm Algorithm 1), we replace the abstract fit call with explicit gradient updates:

Algorithm 2 (Neural Fitted Q-Iteration with Explicit Inner Loop)

Input: MDP (S,A,P,R,γ)(S, A, P, R, \gamma)(S,A,P,R,γ), offline transition dataset D\mathcal{D}D, neural network q(s,a;θ)q(s,a; \boldsymbol{\theta})q(s,a;θ), learning rate α\alphaα, inner optimization steps KKK, initialization θ0\boldsymbol{\theta}_0θ0​

Output: Parameters θ\boldsymbol{\theta}θ for Q-function approximation

  1. Initialize θ0\boldsymbol{\theta}_0θ0​ randomly

  2. n←0n \leftarrow 0n←0 \quad // Outer loop counter (value iteration)

  3. repeat

    1. // Compute Bellman targets using current Q-function

    2. Dnfit←∅\mathcal{D}_n^{\text{fit}} \leftarrow \emptysetDnfit​←∅

    3. for each (s,a,r,s′)∈D(s,a,r,s') \in \mathcal{D}(s,a,r,s′)∈D do

      1. ys,a←r+γmax⁡a′∈Aq(s′,a′;θn)y_{s,a} \leftarrow r + \gamma \max_{a' \in A} q(s',a'; \boldsymbol{\theta}_n)ys,a​←r+γmaxa′∈A​q(s′,a′;θn​)

      2. Dnfit←Dnfit∪{((s,a),ys,a)}\mathcal{D}_n^{\text{fit}} \leftarrow \mathcal{D}_n^{\text{fit}} \cup \{((s,a), y_{s,a})\}Dnfit​←Dnfit​∪{((s,a),ys,a​)}

    4. // Inner optimization loop: fit to targets via gradient descent

    5. θn(0)←θn\boldsymbol{\theta}_n^{(0)} \leftarrow \boldsymbol{\theta}_nθn(0)​←θn​ \quad // Warm start from previous outer iteration

    6. k←0k \leftarrow 0k←0 \quad // Inner loop counter (regression)

    7. repeat

      1. θn(k+1)←θn(k)−α∇θL(θn(k);Dnfit)\boldsymbol{\theta}_n^{(k+1)} \leftarrow \boldsymbol{\theta}_n^{(k)} - \alpha \nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta}_n^{(k)}; \mathcal{D}_n^{\text{fit}})θn(k+1)​←θn(k)​−α∇θ​L(θn(k)​;Dnfit​)

      2. k←k+1k \leftarrow k + 1k←k+1

    8. until k=Kk = Kk=K \quad // Partial optimization: exactly K gradient steps

    9. θn+1←θn(K)\boldsymbol{\theta}_{n+1} \leftarrow \boldsymbol{\theta}_n^{(K)}θn+1​←θn(K)​

    10. n←n+1n \leftarrow n + 1n←n+1

  4. until training complete

  5. return θn\boldsymbol{\theta}_nθn​

This makes the two-level structure completely transparent. The outer loop (indexed by nnn) computes targets ys,a=r+γmax⁡a′q(s′,a′;θn)y_{s,a} = r + \gamma \max_{a'} q(s',a'; \boldsymbol{\theta}_n)ys,a​=r+γmaxa′​q(s′,a′;θn​) using the parameters θn\boldsymbol{\theta}_nθn​ from the end of the previous outer iteration. These targets remain fixed throughout the entire inner loop. The inner loop (indexed by kkk) performs KKK gradient steps to fit q(s,a;θ)q(s,a; \boldsymbol{\theta})q(s,a;θ) to the regression dataset Dnfit={((si,ai),yi)}\mathcal{D}_n^{\text{fit}} = \{((s_i, a_i), y_i)\}Dnfit​={((si​,ai​),yi​)}, warm starting from θn\boldsymbol{\theta}_nθn​ (the parameters that computed the targets). After KKK steps, the inner loop produces θn+1=θn(K)\boldsymbol{\theta}_{n+1} = \boldsymbol{\theta}_n^{(K)}θn+1​=θn(K)​, which becomes the starting point for the next outer iteration.

The notation θn(k)\boldsymbol{\theta}_n^{(k)}θn(k)​ indicates that we are at inner step kkk within outer iteration nnn. The targets depend only on θn=θn(0)\boldsymbol{\theta}_n = \boldsymbol{\theta}_n^{(0)}θn​=θn(0)​, not on the intermediate inner iterates θn(k)\boldsymbol{\theta}_n^{(k)}θn(k)​ for k>0k > 0k>0.

Flattening into a Single Loop¶

We can now flatten the nested structure by treating all gradient steps uniformly and using a global step counter ttt instead of separate outer/inner counters. We introduce a target network θtarget\boldsymbol{\theta}_{\text{target}}θtarget​ that holds the parameters used for computing targets. This target network gets updated every KKK steps, which marks what would have been the boundary between outer iterations. The transformation works as follows: we replace the outer counter nnn and inner counter kkk with a single counter ttt, where t=nK+kt = nK + kt=nK+k. When nnn advances from nnn to n+1n+1n+1, this corresponds to KKK steps of ttt: from t=nKt = nKt=nK to t=(n+1)Kt = (n+1)Kt=(n+1)K. The target network θtarget\boldsymbol{\theta}_{\text{target}}θtarget​ equals θn\boldsymbol{\theta}_nθn​ throughout outer iteration nnn and gets updated via θtarget←θt\boldsymbol{\theta}_{\text{target}} \leftarrow \boldsymbol{\theta}_tθtarget​←θt​ every KKK steps (when t mod K=0t \bmod K = 0tmodK=0). Parameters that were θn(k)\boldsymbol{\theta}_n^{(k)}θn(k)​ in nested form become θt\boldsymbol{\theta}_tθt​ in flattened form.

This transformation is purely algebraic. No algorithmic behavior changes, only the presentation:

Algorithm 3 (Flattened Neural Fitted Q-Iteration)

Input: MDP (S,A,P,R,γ)(S, A, P, R, \gamma)(S,A,P,R,γ), offline transition dataset D\mathcal{D}D, neural network q(s,a;θ)q(s,a; \boldsymbol{\theta})q(s,a;θ), learning rate α\alphaα, target update frequency KKK, initialization θ0\boldsymbol{\theta}_0θ0​

Output: Parameters θ\boldsymbol{\theta}θ for Q-function approximation

  1. Initialize θ0\boldsymbol{\theta}_0θ0​ randomly

  2. θtarget←θ0\boldsymbol{\theta}_{\text{target}} \leftarrow \boldsymbol{\theta}_0θtarget​←θ0​

  3. t←0t \leftarrow 0t←0 \quad // Single flattened loop counter

  4. while training do

    1. // Compute targets using fixed target network

    2. Dtfit←∅\mathcal{D}_t^{\text{fit}} \leftarrow \emptysetDtfit​←∅

    3. for each (s,a,r,s′)∈D(s,a,r,s') \in \mathcal{D}(s,a,r,s′)∈D do

      1. ys,a←r+γmax⁡a′∈Aq(s′,a′;θtarget)y_{s,a} \leftarrow r + \gamma \max_{a' \in A} q(s',a'; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{\text{target}})ys,a​←r+γmaxa′∈A​q(s′,a′;θtarget​)

      2. Dtfit←Dtfit∪{((s,a),ys,a)}\mathcal{D}_t^{\text{fit}} \leftarrow \mathcal{D}_t^{\text{fit}} \cup \{((s,a), y_{s,a})\}Dtfit​←Dtfit​∪{((s,a),ys,a​)}

    4. // Gradient step on online network

    5. θt+1←θt−α∇θL(θt;Dtfit)\boldsymbol{\theta}_{t+1} \leftarrow \boldsymbol{\theta}_t - \alpha \nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta}_t; \mathcal{D}_t^{\text{fit}})θt+1​←θt​−α∇θ​L(θt​;Dtfit​)

    6. // Periodic target network update (marks outer iteration boundary)

    7. if t mod K=0t \bmod K = 0tmodK=0 then

      1. θtarget←θt\boldsymbol{\theta}_{\text{target}} \leftarrow \boldsymbol{\theta}_tθtarget​←θt​

    8. t←t+1t \leftarrow t + 1t←t+1

  5. return θt\boldsymbol{\theta}_tθt​

At step ttt, we have n=⌊t/K⌋n = \lfloor t/K \rfloorn=⌊t/K⌋ (outer iteration) and k=t mod Kk = t \bmod Kk=tmodK (position within inner loop). The target network θtarget\boldsymbol{\theta}_{\text{target}}θtarget​ equals θn\boldsymbol{\theta}_nθn​ throughout the KKK steps from t=nKt = nKt=nK to t=(n+1)K−1t = (n+1)K - 1t=(n+1)K−1, then gets updated to θn+1\boldsymbol{\theta}_{n+1}θn+1​ at t=(n+1)Kt = (n+1)Kt=(n+1)K. The parameters θt\boldsymbol{\theta}_tθt​ correspond to θn(k)\boldsymbol{\theta}_n^{(k)}θn(k)​ in the nested form. The flattening reindexes the iteration structure: with K=10K=10K=10, outer iteration n=3n=3n=3, inner step k=7k=7k=7 becomes global step t=3⋅10+7=37t = 3 \cdot 10 + 7 = 37t=3⋅10+7=37.

Flattening replaces the pair (n,k)(n,k)(n,k) by a single global step index ttt, but the underlying empirical distribution P^D\hat{P}_{\mathcal{D}}P^D​ remains the same. We still sample from the fixed offline dataset throughout.

The target network arises directly from flattening the nested FQI structure. When DQN is presented with a target network that updates every KKK steps, this is approximate value iteration in flattened form. The algorithm still performs outer loop (value iteration) and inner loop (regression), but the presentation obscures this structure. The periodic target updates mark the boundaries between outer iterations. DQN is batch approximate DP in flattened form, using online data collection with a replay buffer.

Smooth Target Updates via Exponential Moving Average¶

An alternative to periodic hard updates is exponential moving average (EMA) (also called Polyak averaging), which updates the target network smoothly at every step rather than synchronizing it every KKK steps:

Algorithm 4 (Flattened Neural Fitted Q-Iteration with EMA Target Updates)

Input: MDP (S,A,P,R,γ)(S, A, P, R, \gamma)(S,A,P,R,γ), offline transition dataset D\mathcal{D}D, neural network q(s,a;θ)q(s,a; \boldsymbol{\theta})q(s,a;θ), learning rate α\alphaα, EMA rate τ∈(0,1)\tau \in (0, 1)τ∈(0,1), initialization θ0\boldsymbol{\theta}_0θ0​

Output: Parameters θ\boldsymbol{\theta}θ for Q-function approximation

  1. Initialize θ0\boldsymbol{\theta}_0θ0​ randomly

  2. θtarget←θ0\boldsymbol{\theta}_{\text{target}} \leftarrow \boldsymbol{\theta}_0θtarget​←θ0​

  3. t←0t \leftarrow 0t←0 \quad // Single flattened loop counter

  4. while training do

    1. // Compute targets using fixed target network

    2. Dtfit←∅\mathcal{D}_t^{\text{fit}} \leftarrow \emptysetDtfit​←∅

    3. for each (s,a,r,s′)∈D(s,a,r,s') \in \mathcal{D}(s,a,r,s′)∈D do

      1. ys,a←r+γmax⁡a′∈Aq(s′,a′;θtarget)y_{s,a} \leftarrow r + \gamma \max_{a' \in A} q(s',a'; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{\text{target}})ys,a​←r+γmaxa′∈A​q(s′,a′;θtarget​)

      2. Dtfit←Dtfit∪{((s,a),ys,a)}\mathcal{D}_t^{\text{fit}} \leftarrow \mathcal{D}_t^{\text{fit}} \cup \{((s,a), y_{s,a})\}Dtfit​←Dtfit​∪{((s,a),ys,a​)}

    4. // Gradient step on online network

    5. θt+1←θt−α∇θL(θt;Dtfit)\boldsymbol{\theta}_{t+1} \leftarrow \boldsymbol{\theta}_t - \alpha \nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta}_t; \mathcal{D}_t^{\text{fit}})θt+1​←θt​−α∇θ​L(θt​;Dtfit​)

    6. // ← CHANGED: Smooth EMA update at every step

    7. θtarget←τθt+1+(1−τ)θtarget\boldsymbol{\theta}_{\text{target}} \leftarrow \tau\boldsymbol{\theta}_{t+1} + (1-\tau)\boldsymbol{\theta}_{\text{target}}θtarget​←τθt+1​+(1−τ)θtarget​

    8. t←t+1t \leftarrow t + 1t←t+1

  5. return θt\boldsymbol{\theta}_tθt​

With EMA updates, the target network slowly tracks the online network instead of making discrete jumps. For small τ\tauτ (typically τ∈[0.001,0.01]\tau \in [0.001, 0.01]τ∈[0.001,0.01]), the target lags behind the online network by roughly 1/τ1/\tau1/τ steps. This provides smoother learning dynamics and avoids the discontinuous changes in targets that occur with periodic hard updates. The EMA approach became popular with DDPG Lillicrap et al. (2015) for continuous control and is now standard in algorithms like TD3 Fujimoto et al. (2018) and SAC Haarnoja et al. (2018).

Online Algorithms: DQN and Extensions¶

We now keep the same fitted Q-iteration template but allow the buffer Bt\mathcal{B}_tBt​ and its empirical distribution P^Bt\hat{P}_{\mathcal{B}_t}P^Bt​​ to evolve while we learn. Instead of repeatedly sampling from a fixed P^D\hat{P}_{\mathcal{D}}P^D​, we collect new transitions during learning and store them in a circular replay buffer.

Note that “online” here takes on a second meaning: we collect data online (interacting with the environment) while also maintaining the online network (actively-updated parameters θt\boldsymbol{\theta}_tθt​) and target network (frozen parameters θtarget\boldsymbol{\theta}_{\text{target}}θtarget​) distinction from the flattened FQI structure. The online network now plays a dual role: it is both the parameters being trained and the policy used to collect new data for the buffer.

Deep Q-Network (DQN) instantiates the online template with moderate choices along the design axes: buffer capacity B≈106B \approx 10^6B≈106, mini-batch size b≈32b \approx 32b≈32, and target network update frequency K≈104K \approx 10^4K≈104. DQN is not an ad hoc collection of tricks. It is fitted Q-iteration in flattened form (as developed in the nested-to-flattened transformation earlier) with an evolving buffer Bt\mathcal{B}_tBt​ and low replay ratio.

Deep Q-Network (DQN)¶

Deep Q-Network (DQN) maintains a circular replay buffer of capacity BBB (typically B≈106B \approx 10^6B≈106). At each environment step, we store the new transition and sample a mini-batch of size bbb from the buffer for training. This increases the replay ratio, reducing gradient variance at the cost of older, potentially off-policy data.

DQN uses two copies of the Q-network parameters:

  • The online network θt\boldsymbol{\theta}_tθt​: actively updated at each gradient step (corresponds to θn(k)\boldsymbol{\theta}_n^{(k)}θn(k)​ in the nested view). It serves a dual role: (1) the policy for collecting new data via ε\varepsilonε-greedy action selection, and (2) the parameters being trained.

  • The target network θtarget\boldsymbol{\theta}_{\text{target}}θtarget​: frozen parameters updated every KKK steps (corresponds to θn\boldsymbol{\theta}_nθn​ in the nested view). Used only for computing Bellman targets.

As shown in the nested-to-flattened section, the target network is not a stabilization trick but the natural consequence of periodic outer-iteration boundaries in flattened FQI. The target network keeps targets fixed for KKK gradient steps, which corresponds to the inner loop in the nested view:

Algorithm 5 (Deep Q-Network (DQN))

Input: MDP (S,A,P,R,γ)(S, A, P, R, \gamma)(S,A,P,R,γ), neural network q(s,a;θ)q(s,a; \boldsymbol{\theta})q(s,a;θ), learning rate α\alphaα, target update frequency KKK, replay buffer capacity BBB, mini-batch size bbb, exploration rate ε\varepsilonε

Output: Parameters θ\boldsymbol{\theta}θ for Q-function approximation

  1. Initialize θ0\boldsymbol{\theta}_0θ0​ randomly

  2. θtarget←θ0\boldsymbol{\theta}_{\text{target}} \leftarrow \boldsymbol{\theta}_0θtarget​←θ0​

  3. Initialize replay buffer B\mathcal{B}B with capacity BBB

  4. t←0t \leftarrow 0t←0

  5. while training do

    1. Observe current state sss

    2. // Use online network to collect data

    3. Select action: a←{arg⁡max⁡a′q(s,a′;θt)with probability 1−εrandom actionwith probability εa \leftarrow \begin{cases} \arg\max_{a'} q(s,a';\boldsymbol{\theta}_t) & \text{with probability } 1-\varepsilon \\ \text{random action} & \text{with probability } \varepsilon \end{cases}a←{argmaxa′​q(s,a′;θt​)random action​with probability 1−εwith probability ε​

    4. Execute aaa, observe reward rrr and next state s′s's′

    5. Store (s,a,r,s′)(s,a,r,s')(s,a,r,s′) in B\mathcal{B}B, replacing oldest if full

    6. Sample mini-batch of bbb transitions {(si,ai,ri,si′)}i=1b\{(s_i,a_i,r_i,s_i')\}_{i=1}^b{(si​,ai​,ri​,si′​)}i=1b​ from B\mathcal{B}B

    7. For each sampled transition (si,ai,ri,si′)(s_i,a_i,r_i,s_i')(si​,ai​,ri​,si′​):

      1. yi←ri+γmax⁡a′∈Aq(si′,a′;θtarget)y_i \leftarrow r_i + \gamma \color{blue}{\max_{a' \in A} q(s_i',a'; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{\text{target}})}yi​←ri​+γmaxa′∈A​q(si′​,a′;θtarget​) (both selection AND evaluation with target network)

    8. θt+1←θt−α∇θ1b∑i=1b(q(si,ai;θt)−yi)2\boldsymbol{\theta}_{t+1} \leftarrow \boldsymbol{\theta}_t - \alpha \nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \frac{1}{b}\sum_{i=1}^b (q(s_i,a_i;\boldsymbol{\theta}_t) - y_i)^2θt+1​←θt​−α∇θ​b1​∑i=1b​(q(si​,ai​;θt​)−yi​)2

    9. if t mod K=0t \bmod K = 0tmodK=0 then

      1. θtarget←θt\boldsymbol{\theta}_{\text{target}} \leftarrow \boldsymbol{\theta}_tθtarget​←θt​

    10. t←t+1t \leftarrow t + 1t←t+1

  6. return θt\boldsymbol{\theta}_tθt​

Double Deep Q-Network (Double DQN)¶

Double DQN addresses overestimation bias by decoupling action selection from evaluation. Instead of using the target network for both purposes (as DQN does), Double DQN uses the online network (currently-training parameters θt\boldsymbol{\theta}_tθt​) to select which action looks best, then uses the target network (frozen parameters θtarget\boldsymbol{\theta}_{\text{target}}θtarget​) to evaluate that action:

Algorithm 6 (Double Deep Q-Network (Double DQN))

Input: MDP (S,A,P,R,γ)(S, A, P, R, \gamma)(S,A,P,R,γ), neural network q(s,a;θ)q(s,a; \boldsymbol{\theta})q(s,a;θ), learning rate α\alphaα, target update frequency KKK, replay buffer capacity BBB, mini-batch size bbb, exploration rate ε\varepsilonε

Output: Parameters θ\boldsymbol{\theta}θ for Q-function approximation

  1. Initialize θ0\boldsymbol{\theta}_0θ0​ randomly

  2. θtarget←θ0\boldsymbol{\theta}_{\text{target}} \leftarrow \boldsymbol{\theta}_0θtarget​←θ0​

  3. Initialize replay buffer B\mathcal{B}B with capacity BBB

  4. t←0t \leftarrow 0t←0

  5. while training do

    1. Observe current state sss

    2. // Use online network to collect data

    3. Select action: a←{arg⁡max⁡a′q(s,a′;θt)with probability 1−εrandom actionwith probability εa \leftarrow \begin{cases} \arg\max_{a'} q(s,a';\boldsymbol{\theta}_t) & \text{with probability } 1-\varepsilon \\ \text{random action} & \text{with probability } \varepsilon \end{cases}a←{argmaxa′​q(s,a′;θt​)random action​with probability 1−εwith probability ε​

    4. Execute aaa, observe reward rrr and next state s′s's′

    5. Store (s,a,r,s′)(s,a,r,s')(s,a,r,s′) in B\mathcal{B}B, replacing oldest if full

    6. Sample mini-batch of bbb transitions {(si,ai,ri,si′)}i=1b\{(s_i,a_i,r_i,s_i')\}_{i=1}^b{(si​,ai​,ri​,si′​)}i=1b​ from B\mathcal{B}B

    7. For each sampled transition (si,ai,ri,si′)(s_i,a_i,r_i,s_i')(si​,ai​,ri​,si′​):

      1. ai∗←arg⁡max⁡a′∈Aq(si′,a′;θt)a^*_i \leftarrow \color{red}{\arg\max_{a' \in A} q(s_i',a'; \boldsymbol{\theta}_t)}ai∗​←argmaxa′∈A​q(si′​,a′;θt​) (action selection with online network)

      2. yi←ri+γq(si′,ai∗;θtarget)y_i \leftarrow r_i + \gamma \color{green}{q(s_i',a^*_i; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{\text{target}})}yi​←ri​+γq(si′​,ai∗​;θtarget​) (action evaluation with target network)

    8. θt+1←θt−α∇θ1b∑i=1b(q(si,ai;θt)−yi)2\boldsymbol{\theta}_{t+1} \leftarrow \boldsymbol{\theta}_t - \alpha \nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \frac{1}{b}\sum_{i=1}^b (q(s_i,a_i;\boldsymbol{\theta}_t) - y_i)^2θt+1​←θt​−α∇θ​b1​∑i=1b​(q(si​,ai​;θt​)−yi​)2

    9. if t mod K=0t \bmod K = 0tmodK=0 then

      1. θtarget←θt\boldsymbol{\theta}_{\text{target}} \leftarrow \boldsymbol{\theta}_tθtarget​←θt​

    10. t←t+1t \leftarrow t + 1t←t+1

  6. return θt\boldsymbol{\theta}_tθt​

Double DQN leaves Bt\mathcal{B}_tBt​ and P^Bt\hat{P}_{\mathcal{B}_t}P^Bt​​ unchanged and modifies only the target function ggg by decoupling action selection (online network) from evaluation (target network). Compare the two approaches:

  • DQN (blue): Uses the target network θtarget\boldsymbol{\theta}_{\text{target}}θtarget​ for BOTH selecting which action is best AND evaluating it: max⁡a′q(s′,a′;θtarget)\max_{a'} q(s',a'; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{\text{target}})maxa′​q(s′,a′;θtarget​) implicitly finds a∗=arg⁡max⁡a′q(s′,a′;θtarget)a^* = \arg\max_{a'} q(s',a'; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{\text{target}})a∗=argmaxa′​q(s′,a′;θtarget​) and then evaluates q(s′,a∗;θtarget)q(s',a^*; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{\text{target}})q(s′,a∗;θtarget​)

  • Double DQN (red + green): Uses the online network θt\boldsymbol{\theta}_tθt​ to select a∗=arg⁡max⁡a′q(s′,a′;θt)a^* = \arg\max_{a'} q(s',a'; \boldsymbol{\theta}_t)a∗=argmaxa′​q(s′,a′;θt​), then uses the target network θtarget\boldsymbol{\theta}_{\text{target}}θtarget​ to evaluate q(s′,a∗;θtarget)q(s',a^*; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{\text{target}})q(s′,a∗;θtarget​)

This decoupling prevents overestimation bias because the noise in action selection (from the online network) is independent of the noise in action evaluation (from the target network). Recall that the online network represents the currently-training parameters being updated at each gradient step, while the target network represents the frozen parameters used for computing targets. By using different parameters for selection versus evaluation, we break the correlation that leads to systematic overestimation in the standard max operator.

Q-Learning: The Limiting Case¶

DQN and Double DQN use moderate settings: B≈106B \approx 10^6B≈106, K≈104K \approx 10^4K≈104, mini-batch size b≈32b \approx 32b≈32. We can ask: what happens at the extreme where we minimize buffer capacity, eliminate replay, and update targets every step? This limiting case gives classical Q-learning Watkins (1989): buffer capacity B=1B=1B=1, target network frequency K=1K=1K=1, and mini-batch size b=1b=1b=1.

In the buffer perspective, Q-learning has Bt={(st,at,rt,st′)}\mathcal{B}_t = \{(s_t, a_t, r_t, s'_t)\}Bt​={(st​,at​,rt​,st′​)} with ∣Bt∣=1|\mathcal{B}_t | = 1∣Bt​∣=1. The empirical distribution P^Bt\hat{P}_{\mathcal{B}_t}P^Bt​​ collapses to a Dirac mass at the current transition. We use each transition exactly once then discard it. There is no separate target network: the parameters used for computing targets are immediately updated after each step (K=1K=1K=1, or equivalently τ=1\tau=1τ=1 in EMA). This makes Q-learning a stochastic approximation method with replay ratio 1.

Stochastic approximation is a general framework for solving equations of the form E[h(X;θ)]=0\mathbb{E}[h(X; \boldsymbol{\theta})] = 0E[h(X;θ)]=0 using noisy samples, without computing expectations explicitly. The classic example is root-finding: given function f(θ;Z)f(\boldsymbol{\theta}; Z)f(θ;Z) whose expectation E[f(θ;Z)]=F(θ)\mathbb{E}[f(\boldsymbol{\theta}; Z)] = F(\boldsymbol{\theta})E[f(θ;Z)]=F(θ) we want to solve F(θ)=0F(\boldsymbol{\theta}) = 0F(θ)=0, the Robbins-Monro procedure updates:

θt+1=θt−αtf(θt;Zt)\boldsymbol{\theta}_{t+1} = \boldsymbol{\theta}_t - \alpha_t f(\boldsymbol{\theta}_t; Z_t)θt+1​=θt​−αt​f(θt​;Zt​)
(13)

using noisy samples ZtZ_tZt​ without ever computing F(θ)F(\boldsymbol{\theta})F(θ) or its Jacobian. This is analogous to Newton’s method in the deterministic case, but replaces exact gradients with stochastic estimates and avoids computing or inverting the Jacobian. Under diminishing step sizes (αt→0\alpha_t \to 0αt​→0, ∑tαt=∞\sum_t \alpha_t = \infty∑t​αt​=∞), the iterates converge to solutions of F(θ)=0F(\boldsymbol{\theta}) = 0F(θ)=0.

Q-learning fits this framework by solving the Bellman residual equation. Recall from the projection methods chapter that the Bellman equation q∗=Lq∗q^* = \Bellman q^*q∗=Lq∗ can be written as a residual equation N(q)≡Lq−q=0\Residual(q) \equiv \Bellman q - q = 0N(q)≡Lq−q=0. For a parameterized Q-function q(s,a;θ)q(s,a; \boldsymbol{\theta})q(s,a;θ), the residual at observed transition (s,a,r,s′)(s,a,r,s')(s,a,r,s′) is:

R(s,a,r,s′;θ)=r+γmax⁡a′q(s′,a′;θ)−q(s,a;θ)R(s,a,r,s'; \boldsymbol{\theta}) = r + \gamma \max_{a'} q(s',a'; \boldsymbol{\theta}) - q(s,a; \boldsymbol{\theta})R(s,a,r,s′;θ)=r+γa′max​q(s′,a′;θ)−q(s,a;θ)
(14)

This is the TD error. Q-learning is a stochastic approximation method for solving Eτ∼P[R(τ;θ)]=0\mathbb{E}_{\tau \sim P}[R(\tau; \boldsymbol{\theta})] = 0Eτ∼P​[R(τ;θ)]=0 where PPP is the distribution of transitions under the behavior policy. Each observed transition provides a noisy sample of the residual, and the algorithm updates parameters using the gradient of the squared residual without computing expectations explicitly.

The algorithm works with any function approximator that supports incremental updates. The general form applies a gradient descent step to minimize the squared TD error. The only difference between linear and nonlinear cases is how the gradient ∇θq(s,a;θ)\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} q(s,a; \boldsymbol{\theta})∇θ​q(s,a;θ) is computed.

Algorithm 7 (Q-Learning)

Input: MDP (S,A,P,R,γ)(S, A, P, R, \gamma)(S,A,P,R,γ), function approximator q(s,a;θ)q(s,a; \boldsymbol{\theta})q(s,a;θ), learning rate α\alphaα, exploration rate ε\varepsilonε

Output: Parameters θ\boldsymbol{\theta}θ for Q-function approximation

  1. Initialize θ0\boldsymbol{\theta}_0θ0​

  2. t←0t \leftarrow 0t←0

  3. while training do

    1. Observe current state sss

    2. Select action: a←{arg⁡max⁡a′∈Aq(s,a′;θt)with probability 1−εrandom actionwith probability εa \leftarrow \begin{cases} \arg\max_{a' \in A} q(s,a';\boldsymbol{\theta}_t) & \text{with probability } 1-\varepsilon \\ \text{random action} & \text{with probability } \varepsilon \end{cases}a←{argmaxa′∈A​q(s,a′;θt​)random action​with probability 1−εwith probability ε​

    3. Execute aaa, observe reward rrr and next state s′s's′

    4. Compute TD target: y←r+γmax⁡a′∈Aq(s′,a′;θt)y \leftarrow r + \gamma \max_{a' \in A} q(s',a'; \boldsymbol{\theta}_t)y←r+γmaxa′∈A​q(s′,a′;θt​)

    5. Update: θt+1←θt−α∇θ(q(s,a;θt)−y)2\boldsymbol{\theta}_{t+1} \leftarrow \boldsymbol{\theta}_t - \alpha \nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} (q(s,a;\boldsymbol{\theta}_t) - y)^2θt+1​←θt​−α∇θ​(q(s,a;θt​)−y)2

    6. t←t+1t \leftarrow t + 1t←t+1

  4. return θt\boldsymbol{\theta}_tθt​

The gradient in line 5 depends on the choice of function approximator:

  • Tabular: Uses one-hot features ϕ(s,a)=e(s,a)\boldsymbol{\phi}(s,a) = \boldsymbol{e}_{(s,a)}ϕ(s,a)=e(s,a)​, giving table-lookup updates Q(s,a)←Q(s,a)+α(r+γmax⁡a′Q(s′,a′)−Q(s,a))Q(s,a) \leftarrow Q(s,a) + \alpha(r + \gamma \max_{a'} Q(s',a') - Q(s,a))Q(s,a)←Q(s,a)+α(r+γmaxa′​Q(s′,a′)−Q(s,a)). Converges under standard stochastic approximation conditions (detailed below).

  • Linear: q(s,a;θ)=θ⊤ϕ(s,a)q(s,a; \boldsymbol{\theta}) = \boldsymbol{\theta}^\top \boldsymbol{\phi}(s,a)q(s,a;θ)=θ⊤ϕ(s,a) where ϕ:S×A→Rd\boldsymbol{\phi}: \mathcal{S} \times \mathcal{A} \to \mathbb{R}^dϕ:S×A→Rd is a feature map. The gradient is ∇θq(s,a;θ)=ϕ(s,a)\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} q(s,a; \boldsymbol{\theta}) = \boldsymbol{\phi}(s,a)∇θ​q(s,a;θ)=ϕ(s,a), giving the update θt+1=θt+α(y−θt⊤ϕ(s,a))ϕ(s,a)\boldsymbol{\theta}_{t+1} = \boldsymbol{\theta}_t + \alpha (y - \boldsymbol{\theta}_t^\top \boldsymbol{\phi}(s,a)) \boldsymbol{\phi}(s,a)θt+1​=θt​+α(y−θt⊤​ϕ(s,a))ϕ(s,a). Convergence is not guaranteed in general; the max operator combined with function approximation can cause instability.

  • Nonlinear: q(s,a;θ)q(s,a; \boldsymbol{\theta})q(s,a;θ) is a neural network with weights θ\boldsymbol{\theta}θ. The gradient ∇θq(s,a;θ)\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} q(s,a; \boldsymbol{\theta})∇θ​q(s,a;θ) is computed via backpropagation. Convergence guarantees do not exist.

Convergence Analysis via the ODE Method¶

Tabular Q-learning converges under diminishing step sizes (αt→0\alpha_t \to 0αt​→0, ∑tαt=∞\sum_t \alpha_t = \infty∑t​αt​=∞) and sufficient exploration Watkins & Dayan (1992)Jaakkola et al. (1994)Tsitsiklis (1994). The standard proof technique is the ordinary differential equation (ODE) method Kushner & Yin (2003)Borkar & Meyn (2000), which analyzes stochastic approximation algorithms by studying an associated deterministic dynamical system.

The ODE method connects stochastic approximation to deterministic dynamics through a two-step argument. First, we show that as step sizes shrink, the discrete stochastic recursion θt+1=θt+αth(θt,Zt)\boldsymbol{\theta}_{t+1} = \boldsymbol{\theta}_t + \alpha_t h(\boldsymbol{\theta}_t, Z_t)θt+1​=θt​+αt​h(θt​,Zt​) tracks the continuous deterministic ODE dθdt=hˉ(θ)\frac{d\boldsymbol{\theta}}{dt} = \bar{h}(\boldsymbol{\theta})dtdθ​=hˉ(θ) where hˉ(θ)=E[h(θ,Z)]\bar{h}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) = \mathbb{E}[h(\boldsymbol{\theta}, Z)]hˉ(θ)=E[h(θ,Z)] is the expected update direction. Second, we prove convergence of the ODE using Lyapunov functions or other dynamical systems tools. If the ODE converges to an equilibrium, the stochastic algorithm converges to the same point.

For tabular Q-learning, the update at state-action pair (s,a)(s,a)(s,a) is:

Qt+1(s,a)=Qt(s,a)+αt[r+γmax⁡a′Qt(s′,a′)−Qt(s,a)]Q_{t+1}(s,a) = Q_t(s,a) + \alpha_t \big[ r + \gamma \max_{a'} Q_t(s',a') - Q_t(s,a) \big]Qt+1​(s,a)=Qt​(s,a)+αt​[r+γa′max​Qt​(s′,a′)−Qt​(s,a)]
(15)

where (s,a,r,s′)(s,a,r,s')(s,a,r,s′) is sampled from the transition distribution PPP induced by the behavior policy. The expected update direction is:

hˉ(Q)(s,a)=E(s,a,r,s′)∼P[r+γmax⁡a′Q(s′,a′)−Q(s,a)∣(s,a) visited]\bar{h}(Q)(s,a) = \mathbb{E}_{(s,a,r,s') \sim P} \big[ r + \gamma \max_{a'} Q(s',a') - Q(s,a) \mid (s,a) \text{ visited} \big]hˉ(Q)(s,a)=E(s,a,r,s′)∼P​[r+γa′max​Q(s′,a′)−Q(s,a)∣(s,a) visited]
(16)

Under sufficient exploration (all state-action pairs visited infinitely often), this expectation is well-defined. Let ξ(s,a)\xi(s,a)ξ(s,a) denote the stationary distribution over state-action pairs under the behavior policy. The ODE becomes:

dQ(s,a)dt=∑s′p(s′∣s,a)[r(s,a,s′)+γmax⁡a′Q(s′,a′)]−Q(s,a)\frac{dQ(s,a)}{dt} = \sum_{s'} p(s'|s,a) \big[r(s,a,s') + \gamma \max_{a'} Q(s',a') \big] - Q(s,a)dtdQ(s,a)​=s′∑​p(s′∣s,a)[r(s,a,s′)+γa′max​Q(s′,a′)]−Q(s,a)
(17)

This is a deterministic dynamical system. The fixed points satisfy Q(s,a)=Es′[r(s,a,s′)+γmax⁡a′Q(s′,a′)]Q(s,a) = \mathbb{E}_{s'}[r(s,a,s') + \gamma \max_{a'} Q(s',a')]Q(s,a)=Es′​[r(s,a,s′)+γmaxa′​Q(s′,a′)], which is the Bellman optimality equation. Convergence is established by showing this ODE has a global Lyapunov function: the distance ∥Q−Q∗∥\|Q - Q^*\|∥Q−Q∗∥ to the optimal Q-function decreases along trajectories. The Bellman operator is a contraction, which ensures the ODE trajectories converge to Q∗Q^*Q∗.

The interaction between the stationary distribution ξ\xiξ and the empirical distribution P^Bt\hat{P}_{\mathcal{B}_t}P^Bt​​ is subtle. In pure stochastic approximation (Q-learning), we have Bt={(st,at,rt,st′)}\mathcal{B}_t = \{(s_t, a_t, r_t, s'_t)\}Bt​={(st​,at​,rt​,st′​)} with a single transition. Over time, as we explore, the sequence of visited state-action pairs (st,at)(s_t, a_t)(st​,at​) follows the behavior policy, and under ergodicity, the empirical frequency with which we update each (s,a)(s,a)(s,a) converges to the stationary distribution ξ(s,a)\xi(s,a)ξ(s,a). The ODE method formalizes this: the expected update hˉ(Q)\bar{h}(Q)hˉ(Q) averages over PPP, which implicitly weights by how often we visit each (s,a)(s,a)(s,a) under the stationary distribution.

For linear Q-learning with function approximation, the ODE analysis becomes more complex. The projection methods chapter shows that non-monotone projections (like linear least squares) can fail to preserve contraction properties. The max operator in Q-learning creates additional complications that prevent general convergence guarantees, even though the algorithm may work in practice for well-chosen features.

Regression Losses and Noise Models¶

Fix a particular time ttt and buffer contents Bt\mathcal{B}_tBt​. Sampling from Bt\mathcal{B}_tBt​ and pushing transitions through the target function g(⋅;θt)g(\cdot; \boldsymbol{\theta}_t)g(⋅;θt​) gives a regression distribution P^tfit\hat{P}_t^{\text{fit}}P^tfit​ over pairs ((s,a),y)((s,a), y)((s,a),y). The fit operation in the inner loop is then a standard statistical estimation problem: given empirical samples from P^tfit\hat{P}_t^{\text{fit}}P^tfit​, choose parameters θ\boldsymbol{\theta}θ to minimize a loss:

L(θ;Bt)≈E((s,a),y)∼P^tfit[ℓ(q(s,a;θ),y)]\mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol{\theta}; \mathcal{B}_t) \approx \mathbb{E}_{((s,a),y)\sim \hat{P}_t^{\text{fit}}} \big[\ell(q(s,a;\boldsymbol{\theta}), y)\big]L(θ;Bt​)≈E((s,a),y)∼P^tfit​​[ℓ(q(s,a;θ),y)]
(18)

The choice of loss ℓ\ellℓ implicitly specifies a noise model for the targets yyy under P^tfit\hat{P}_t^{\text{fit}}P^tfit​. Squared error corresponds to Gaussian noise, absolute error to Laplace noise, Gumbel regression to extreme-value noise, and classification losses to non-parametric noise models over value bins. Because Bellman targets are noisy, biased, and bootstrapped, this choice has a direct impact on how the algorithm interprets the empirical distribution P^tfit\hat{P}_t^{\text{fit}}P^tfit​.

This section examines alternative loss functions for the regression step. The standard approach uses squared error, but the noise in Bellman targets has special structure due to the max operator and bootstrapping. Two strategies have shown empirical success: Gumbel regression, which uses the proper likelihood for extreme-value noise, and classification-based methods, which avoid parametric noise assumptions by working with distributions over value bins.

Gumbel Regression¶

Extreme value theory tells us that the maximum of Gaussian errors has Gumbel-distributed tails. If we take this distribution seriously, maximum likelihood estimation should use a Gumbel likelihood rather than a Gaussian one. Garg, Tang, Kahn, and Levine Garg et al. (2023) developed this idea in Extreme Q-Learning (XQL). Instead of modeling the Bellman error as additive Gaussian noise:

yi=q∗(si,ai)+εi,εi∼N(0,σ2)y_i = q^*(s_i, a_i) + \varepsilon_i, \quad \varepsilon_i \sim \mathcal{N}(0, \sigma^2)yi​=q∗(si​,ai​)+εi​,εi​∼N(0,σ2)
(19)

they model it as Gumbel noise:

yi=q∗(si,ai)+εi,εi∼−Gumbel(0,β)y_i = q^*(s_i, a_i) + \varepsilon_i, \quad \varepsilon_i \sim -\text{Gumbel}(0, \beta)yi​=q∗(si​,ai​)+εi​,εi​∼−Gumbel(0,β)
(20)

The negative Gumbel distribution arises because we are modeling errors in targets that overestimate the true value. The corresponding maximum likelihood loss is Gumbel regression:

LGumbel(θ)=∑i[q(si,ai;θ)−yiβ+exp⁡(q(si,ai;θ)−yiβ)]\mathcal{L}_{\text{Gumbel}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) = \sum_i \left[\frac{q(s_i, a_i; \boldsymbol{\theta}) - y_i}{\beta} + \exp\left(\frac{q(s_i, a_i; \boldsymbol{\theta}) - y_i}{\beta}\right)\right]LGumbel​(θ)=i∑​[βq(si​,ai​;θ)−yi​​+exp(βq(si​,ai​;θ)−yi​​)]
(21)

The temperature parameter β\betaβ controls the heaviness of the tail. The score function (gradient with respect to qqq) is:

∂LGumbel∂q=1β[1+exp⁡(q−yβ)]\frac{\partial \mathcal{L}_{\text{Gumbel}}}{\partial q} = \frac{1}{\beta}\left[1 + \exp\left(\frac{q - y}{\beta}\right)\right]∂q∂LGumbel​​=β1​[1+exp(βq−y​)]
(22)

When q<yq < yq<y (underestimation), the exponential term is small and the gradient is mild. When q>yq > yq>y (overestimation), the gradient grows exponentially with the error. This asymmetry deliberately penalizes overestimation more heavily than underestimation. When targets are systematically biased upward due to the max operator, this loss geometry pushes the estimates toward conservative Q-values.

The Gumbel loss can be understood as the natural likelihood for problems involving max operators, just as the Gaussian is the natural likelihood for problems involving averages. The central limit theorem tells us that sums converge to Gaussians; extreme value theory tells us that maxima converge to Gumbel (for light-tailed base distributions). Squared error is optimal for Gaussian noise; Gumbel regression is optimal for Gumbel noise.

Source
#  label: fig-gumbel-loss
#  caption: Gumbel regression reshapes the loss landscape (left) and gradient geometry (right), penalizing overestimation exponentially while keeping underestimation gentle.

%config InlineBackend.figure_format = 'retina'
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Apply book style
try:
    import scienceplots
    plt.style.use(['science', 'notebook'])
except (ImportError, OSError):
    pass  # Use matplotlib defaults

# Set up the figure with two subplots
fig, (ax1, ax2) = plt.subplots(1, 2, figsize=(12, 4))

# Define error range (q - y)
error = np.linspace(-3, 3, 500)

# Different beta values to show control over asymmetry
betas = [0.5, 1.0, 2.0]
colors = ['#1f77b4', '#ff7f0e', '#2ca02c']
labels = [r'$\beta = 0.5$ (aggressive)', r'$\beta = 1.0$ (moderate)', r'$\beta = 2.0$ (mild)']

# Plot 1: Gumbel loss function
for beta, color, label in zip(betas, colors, labels):
    loss = error / beta + np.exp(error / beta)
    ax1.plot(error, loss, color=color, linewidth=2, label=label)

# Add reference: squared error for comparison
squared_error = error**2
ax1.plot(error, squared_error, 'k--', linewidth=1.5, alpha=0.5, label='Squared error')

ax1.axvline(x=0, color='gray', linestyle=':', alpha=0.5)
ax1.axhline(y=0, color='gray', linestyle=':', alpha=0.5)
ax1.set_xlabel(r'Error: $q - y$', fontsize=11)
ax1.set_ylabel('Loss', fontsize=11)
ax1.set_title('Gumbel Loss Function', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax1.legend(fontsize=9)
ax1.grid(True, alpha=0.3)
ax1.set_ylim([0, 10])

# Annotate regions
ax1.text(-2, 7, 'Underestimation\n' + r'$(q < y)$', 
         fontsize=9, ha='center', color='darkred', alpha=0.7)
ax1.text(2, 7, 'Overestimation\n' + r'$(q > y)$', 
         fontsize=9, ha='center', color='darkblue', alpha=0.7)

# Plot 2: Gradient (score function) - showing asymmetry
for beta, color, label in zip(betas, colors, labels):
    gradient = (1/beta) * (1 + np.exp(error / beta))
    ax2.plot(error, gradient, color=color, linewidth=2, label=label)

# Add reference: gradient of squared error
squared_error_grad = 2 * error
ax2.plot(error, squared_error_grad, 'k--', linewidth=1.5, alpha=0.5, label='Squared error')

ax2.axvline(x=0, color='gray', linestyle=':', alpha=0.5)
ax2.axhline(y=0, color='gray', linestyle=':', alpha=0.5)
ax2.set_xlabel(r'Error: $q - y$', fontsize=11)
ax2.set_ylabel('Gradient magnitude', fontsize=11)
ax2.set_title('Gumbel Loss Gradient (Score Function)', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax2.legend(fontsize=9)
ax2.grid(True, alpha=0.3)
ax2.set_ylim([-5, 10])

# Annotate asymmetry
ax2.text(-2, -3, 'Mild gradient\n(tolerates underestimation)', 
         fontsize=9, ha='center', color='darkred', alpha=0.7)
ax2.text(2, 7, 'Steep gradient\n(penalizes overestimation)', 
         fontsize=9, ha='center', color='darkblue', alpha=0.7)

plt.tight_layout()

The left panel shows the Gumbel loss as a function of the error q−yq - yq−y. Notice the asymmetry: the loss grows exponentially for positive errors (overestimation) but increases only linearly for negative errors (underestimation). The parameter β\betaβ controls the degree of this asymmetry—smaller β\betaβ values create more aggressive penalization of overestimation.

The right panel shows the gradient (score function), which determines how strongly the optimizer pushes back against errors. For overestimation (q>yq > yq>y), the gradient grows exponentially, creating strong corrective pressure. For underestimation (q<yq < yq<y), the gradient remains relatively flat (approaching 1/β1/\beta1/β). This is in stark contrast to squared error (dashed line), which treats over- and underestimation symmetrically. By tuning β\betaβ, we can calibrate how aggressively the loss combats the overestimation bias induced by the max operator in the Bellman target.

Remark 5 (XQL vs Soft Q-Learning: Target Function vs Loss)

XQL (Gumbel loss) and Soft Q-learning both involve Gumbel distributions, but they operate at different levels of the FQI template. Recall our unified framework: buffer Bt\mathcal{B}_tBt​, target function ggg, loss ℓ\ellℓ, optimization budget KKK.

Soft Q-learning changes the target function by using the smooth Bellman operator from regularized MDPs:

gsoft(s,a,r,s′;θ)=r+γ1βlog⁡∑a′exp⁡(βq(s′,a′;θ))g^{\text{soft}}(s,a,r,s'; \boldsymbol{\theta}) = r + \gamma \frac{1}{\beta}\log\sum_{a'} \exp(\beta q(s',a'; \boldsymbol{\theta}))gsoft(s,a,r,s′;θ)=r+γβ1​loga′∑​exp(βq(s′,a′;θ))
(23)

This replaces the hard max with logsumexp for entropy regularization. The loss remains standard: ℓ(q,y)=(q−y)2\ell(q,y) = (q-y)^2ℓ(q,y)=(q−y)2. The Gumbel distribution appears through the Gumbel-max trick (logsumexp = soft max), but this is about making the optimal policy stochastic, not about the noise structure in TD errors.

XQL keeps the hard max target function:

ghard(s,a,r,s′;θ)=r+γmax⁡a′q(s′,a′;θ)g^{\text{hard}}(s,a,r,s'; \boldsymbol{\theta}) = r + \gamma \max_{a'} q(s',a'; \boldsymbol{\theta})ghard(s,a,r,s′;θ)=r+γa′max​q(s′,a′;θ)
(24)

and instead changes the loss to Gumbel regression: ℓGumbel(q,y)=q−yβ+exp⁡(q−yβ)\ell_{\text{Gumbel}}(q,y) = \frac{q-y}{\beta} + \exp(\frac{q-y}{\beta})ℓGumbel​(q,y)=βq−y​+exp(βq−y​). The Gumbel distribution here models the noise in the TD errors themselves, not the policy.

The asymmetric penalization in XQL (exponential penalty for overestimation) comes from the score function of the Gumbel likelihood, which is designed to handle extreme-value noise. Soft Q-learning uses symmetric L2 loss, so it does not preferentially penalize overestimation. The logsumexp smoothing in Soft Q reduces maximization bias by averaging over actions, but this is a property of the target function, not the loss geometry.

Both can be combined: Soft Q-learning with Gumbel loss would change both the target function (logsumexp) and the loss (asymmetric penalization).

The practical advantage of XQL is that the loss function itself handles the asymmetric error structure through its score function. We do not need to estimate variances or compute weighted averages. XQL has shown improvements in both value-based and actor-critic methods, particularly in offline reinforcement learning where the max-operator bias compounds across iterations without corrective exploration.

Classification-Based Q-Learning¶

From the buffer viewpoint, nothing changes upstream: we still sample transitions from P^Bt\hat{P}_{\mathcal{B}_t}P^Bt​​ and apply the same target function g(⋅;θt)g(\cdot; \boldsymbol{\theta}_t)g(⋅;θt​). Classification-based Q-learning changes only the loss ℓ\ellℓ and target representation. Instead of regressing on a scalar y∈Ry\in\mathbb{R}y∈R with L2, we represent values as categorical distributions over bins and use cross-entropy loss.

Choose a finite grid z1<z2<⋯<zKz_1 < z_2 < \cdots < z_Kz1​<z2​<⋯<zK​ spanning plausible return values. The network outputs logits ℓθ(s,a)∈RK\ell_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(s,a) \in \mathbb{R}^Kℓθ​(s,a)∈RK converted to probabilities:

pθ(k∣s,a)=exp⁡(ℓθ(s,a)k)∑j=1Kexp⁡(ℓθ(s,a)j),q(s,a;θ)=∑k=1Kzk pθ(k∣s,a)p_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(k \mid s,a) = \frac{\exp(\ell_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(s,a)_k)}{\sum_{j=1}^K \exp(\ell_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(s,a)_j)}, \quad q(s,a; \boldsymbol{\theta}) = \sum_{k=1}^K z_k \, p_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(k \mid s,a)pθ​(k∣s,a)=∑j=1K​exp(ℓθ​(s,a)j​)exp(ℓθ​(s,a)k​)​,q(s,a;θ)=k=1∑K​zk​pθ​(k∣s,a)
(25)

Each scalar TD target yiy_iyi​ is converted to a target distribution via the two-hot encoding. If yiy_iyi​ falls between bins zjz_jzj​ and zj+1z_{j+1}zj+1​:

qj(yi)=zj+1−yizj+1−zj,qj+1(yi)=yi−zjzj+1−zj,qk(yi)=0 for k∉{j,j+1}q_j(y_i) = \frac{z_{j+1} - y_i}{z_{j+1} - z_j}, \quad q_{j+1}(y_i) = \frac{y_i - z_j}{z_{j+1} - z_j}, \quad q_k(y_i) = 0 \text{ for } k \notin \{j, j+1\}qj​(yi​)=zj+1​−zj​zj+1​−yi​​,qj+1​(yi​)=zj+1​−zj​yi​−zj​​,qk​(yi​)=0 for k∈/{j,j+1}
(26)

This is barycentric interpolation: ∑kzkqk(yi)=yi\sum_k z_k q_k(y_i) = y_i∑k​zk​qk​(yi​)=yi​ recovers the scalar exactly, placing the two-hot encoding within the same framework as linear interpolation in the dynamic programming chapter (Algorithm Algorithm 2).

Source
#  label: fig-two-hot
#  caption: Two-hot encoding as barycentric interpolation: the left panel shows a single target spread over two bins, while the right panel compares encodings for multiple targets.

%config InlineBackend.figure_format = 'retina'
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Apply book style
try:
    import scienceplots
    plt.style.use(['science', 'notebook'])
except (ImportError, OSError):
    pass  # Use matplotlib defaults

def two_hot_encode(y, z_bins):
    """Compute two-hot encoding weights for target value y on grid z_bins."""
    K = len(z_bins)
    q = np.zeros(K)
    
    # Clip to grid boundaries
    if y <= z_bins[0]:
        q[0] = 1.0
        return q, 0
    if y >= z_bins[-1]:
        q[-1] = 1.0
        return q, K - 1
    
    # Find bins j, j+1 such that z_j <= y < z_{j+1}
    j = np.searchsorted(z_bins, y, side='right') - 1
    
    # Barycentric coordinates (linear interpolation)
    q[j+1] = (y - z_bins[j]) / (z_bins[j+1] - z_bins[j])
    q[j] = (z_bins[j+1] - y) / (z_bins[j+1] - z_bins[j])
    
    return q, j

# Set up the figure with two panels
fig, (ax1, ax2) = plt.subplots(1, 2, figsize=(12, 4))

# Define a grid of K=11 bins spanning [-5, 5]
K = 11
z_bins = np.linspace(-5, 5, K)

# Panel 1: Two-hot encoding for a specific target
y_target = 0.7
q, j = two_hot_encode(y_target, z_bins)

# Plot bins as vertical lines
for z in z_bins:
    ax1.axvline(z, color='lightgray', linestyle='--', linewidth=0.8, alpha=0.5)

# Plot the distribution
colors_bar = ['#E63946' if qi > 0 else '#A8DADC' for qi in q]
ax1.bar(z_bins, q, width=(z_bins[1] - z_bins[0]) * 0.8, 
        color=colors_bar, alpha=0.7, edgecolor='black', linewidth=1.5)

# Highlight the target value
ax1.axvline(y_target, color='#2E86AB', linewidth=3, label=f'Target $y = {y_target}$', zorder=10)
ax1.plot(y_target, 0, 'o', color='#2E86AB', markersize=12, zorder=11)

# Annotate the two active bins with barycentric coordinates
ax1.annotate(f'$q_{{{j}}} = {q[j]:.3f}$\n$= \\frac{{z_{{{j+1}}} - y}}{{z_{{{j+1}}} - z_{{{j}}}}}$',
            xy=(z_bins[j], q[j]), xytext=(z_bins[j] - 1.8, q[j] + 0.25),
            fontsize=10, color='#E63946', weight='bold',
            arrowprops=dict(arrowstyle='->', color='#E63946', lw=2))
ax1.annotate(f'$q_{{{j+1}}} = {q[j+1]:.3f}$\n$= \\frac{{y - z_{{{j}}}}}{{z_{{{j+1}}} - z_{{{j}}}}}$',
            xy=(z_bins[j+1], q[j+1]), xytext=(z_bins[j+1] + 0.5, q[j+1] + 0.25),
            fontsize=10, color='#E63946', weight='bold',
            arrowprops=dict(arrowstyle='->', color='#E63946', lw=2))

# Verify barycentric property
reconstruction = np.sum(z_bins * q)
textstr = f'Barycentric property:\n$\\sum_k z_k q_k(y) = {reconstruction:.4f} = y$'
ax1.text(0.02, 0.97, textstr, transform=ax1.transAxes, fontsize=10,
        verticalalignment='top', bbox=dict(boxstyle='round', facecolor='wheat', alpha=0.8))

ax1.set_xlabel('Bin value $z_k$', fontsize=11)
ax1.set_ylabel('Probability $q_k(y)$', fontsize=11)
ax1.set_title('Two-Hot Encoding = Linear Interpolation', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax1.set_ylim([0, 1.2])
ax1.legend(loc='upper right', fontsize=10)
ax1.grid(axis='y', alpha=0.3)

# Panel 2: Multiple targets to show the pattern
targets = [0.7, -2.3, 3.8]
colors = ['#2E86AB', '#A23B72', '#F18F01']

for idx, (y_target, color) in enumerate(zip(targets, colors)):
    q, _ = two_hot_encode(y_target, z_bins)
    offset = idx * 0.2
    ax2.bar(z_bins + offset, q, width=0.18, color=color, alpha=0.7, 
           label=f'$y = {y_target}$', edgecolor='black', linewidth=0.8)

for z in z_bins:
    ax2.axvline(z, color='lightgray', linestyle='--', linewidth=0.5, alpha=0.4)

ax2.set_xlabel('Bin value $z_k$', fontsize=11)
ax2.set_ylabel('Probability $q_k(y)$', fontsize=11)
ax2.set_title('Multiple Targets: Each Encoded as Two-Hot', fontsize=12, fontweight='bold')
ax2.legend(loc='upper right', fontsize=10)
ax2.grid(axis='y', alpha=0.3)

plt.tight_layout()

The left panel shows two-hot encoding for y=0.7y=0.7y=0.7 on a grid of 11 bins. The target value is distributed over exactly two adjacent bins zjz_jzj​ and zj+1z_{j+1}zj+1​ with weights that are barycentric coordinates: the weight assigned to each bin is inversely proportional to the distance from the target to that bin. The inset verifies that ∑kzkqk(y)\sum_k z_k q_k(y)∑k​zk​qk​(y) exactly recovers the original target—this is the same linear interpolation formula used throughout the book. The right panel shows that different targets produce different two-hot patterns, each concentrating mass on the two bins surrounding the target value.

The loss minimizes cross-entropy:

LCE(θ)=−E((s,a),y)∼P^tfit[∑k=1Kqk(y)log⁡pθ(k∣s,a)]\mathcal{L}_{\text{CE}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) = -\mathbb{E}_{((s,a),y) \sim \hat{P}_t^{\text{fit}}}\left[ \sum_{k=1}^K q_k(y) \log p_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(k \mid s, a) \right]LCE​(θ)=−E((s,a),y)∼P^tfit​​[k=1∑K​qk​(y)logpθ​(k∣s,a)]
(27)

which projects the target distribution onto the predicted distribution in KL geometry on the simplex ΔK−1\Delta^{K-1}ΔK−1 rather than L2 on R\mathbb{R}R. The gradient is ∇ℓθLCE=pθ−q\nabla_{\ell_\theta} \mathcal{L}_{\text{CE}} = p_\theta - q∇ℓθ​​LCE​=pθ​−q, bounded in magnitude regardless of target size.

This provides three sources of implicit robustness. First, gradient influence is bounded: each sample contributes O(1)O(1)O(1) gradient magnitude per bin, unlike L2 where error magnitude EEE contributes gradient proportional to EEE. Second, the finite grid [z1,zK][z_1, z_K][z1​,zK​] clips extreme targets to boundary bins, preventing outliers from dominating the regression scale. Third, the two-hot encoding spreads mass across neighboring bins, providing label smoothing that averages noisy targets at the same (s,a)(s,a)(s,a).

The two-hot weights qj(yi),qj+1(yi)q_j(y_i), q_{j+1}(y_i)qj​(yi​),qj+1​(yi​) are barycentric coordinates, identical to linear interpolation in the dynamic programming chapter (Algorithm Algorithm 2). This places the encoding within Gordon’s monotone approximator framework (Definition Definition 1): targets are convex combinations preserving order and boundedness. The neural network predicting pθ(⋅∣s,a)p_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(\cdot \mid s,a)pθ​(⋅∣s,a) is non-monotone, making classification-based Q-learning a hybrid: monotone target structure paired with flexible function approximation.

Empirically, cross-entropy loss scales better with network capacity. Farebrother et al. Farebrother et al. (2024) found that L2-based DQN and CQL degrade when Q-networks scale to large ResNets, while classification loss (specifically HL-Gauss, which uses Gaussian smoothing instead of two-hot) maintains performance. The combination of KL geometry, quantization, and smoothing prevents overfitting to noisy targets that plagues L2 with high-capacity networks.

Summary¶

Fitted Q-iteration has a two-level structure: an outer loop applies the Bellman operator to construct targets, an inner loop fits a function approximator to those targets. All algorithms in this chapter instantiate this template with different choices of buffer Bt\mathcal{B}_tBt​, target function ggg, loss ℓ\ellℓ, and optimization budget KKK.

The empirical distribution P^Bt\hat{P}_{\mathcal{B}_t}P^Bt​​ unifies offline and online methods through plug-in approximation: replace unknown transition law PPP with P^Bt\hat{P}_{\mathcal{B}_t}P^Bt​​ and minimize empirical risk E((s,a),y)∼P^tfit[ℓ(q,y)]\mathbb{E}_{((s,a),y)\sim \hat{P}_t^{\text{fit}}} [\ell(q, y)]E((s,a),y)∼P^tfit​​[ℓ(q,y)]. Offline uses fixed Bt≡D\mathcal{B}_t \equiv \mathcal{D}Bt​≡D (sample average approximation), online uses circular buffer (Q-learning with B=1B=1B=1 is stochastic approximation, DQN with large BBB is hybrid).

Target networks and online networks arise from flattening the nested loops. Merging inner gradient steps with outer value iteration creates a single loop where two sets of parameters coexist: the online network θt\boldsymbol{\theta}_tθt​ (actively updated at each gradient step, corresponds to θn(k)\boldsymbol{\theta}_n^{(k)}θn(k)​) and the target network θtarget\boldsymbol{\theta}_{\text{target}}θtarget​ (frozen for computing targets, updated every KKK steps to mark outer-iteration boundaries, corresponds to θn\boldsymbol{\theta}_nθn​). In online algorithms like DQN, the online network additionally serves as the behavior policy for data collection.

The next chapter directly parameterizes and optimizes policies instead of searching over value functions.
